revision.comment: Reverted 6 edits by Aidanskymcgervey: /θ, ð, x/ are certainly not the only "non-universal phonemes" — for instance /h/ isn't present in Cockney any many other dialects of England; there is no [ŋ] except in [ŋɡ, ŋk] /nɡ, nk/ in Scouse; etc. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{selfref|For assistance with IPA transcriptions of English for Wikipedia articles, see [[Help:IPA/English]].}} {{See also|Phonological history of English}} {{English phonology topics}} Like many other languages, [[English language|English]] has wide variation in [[pronunciation]], both [[History of the English language|historically]] and from [[List of dialects of the English language|dialect to dialect]]. In general, however, the regional dialects of English share a largely similar (but not identical) [[phonology|phonological]] system. Among other things, most dialects have [[vowel reduction]] in [[unstressed]] [[syllable]]s and a complex set of [[phonological feature]]s that distinguish [[fortis and lenis]] [[consonant]]s ([[stop consonant|stops]], [[affricate]]s, and [[fricative]]s). Most dialects of English preserve the consonant {{IPA|/w/}} (spelled {{angbr|w}}) and many preserve {{IPA|/θ, ð/}} (spelled {{angbr|th}}), while most other Germanic languages have shifted them to {{IPA|/v/}} and {{IPA|/t, d/}}: compare English ''will'' {{IPAc-en|audio=En-us-will.ogg|w|ɪ|l}} and ''then'' {{IPAc-en|audio=En-us-then.ogg|ð|ɛ|n}} with German {{wikt-lang|de|will}} {{IPA-de|vɪl||De-will.ogg}} ('want') and {{wikt-lang|de|denn}} {{IPA-de|dɛn||De-denn.ogg}} ('because'). Phonological analysis of English often concentrates on or uses, as a reference point, one or more of the [[prestige (sociolinguistics)|prestige]] or [[standard language|standard]] accents, such as [[Received Pronunciation]] for [[England]], [[General American]] for the [[United States]], and [[Australian English|General Australian]] for [[Australia]]. Nevertheless, many other dialects of English are spoken, which have developed independently from these standardized accents, particularly regional dialects. Information about these standardized accents functions only as a ''limited'' guide to all of '''English phonology''', which one can later expand upon once one becomes more familiar with some of the many other dialects of English that are spoken. ==Phonemes== A [[phoneme]] of a language or dialect is an [[abstraction]] of a [[speech sound]] or of a group of different sounds which are all perceived to have the same function by speakers of that particular language or dialect. For example, the English word ''through'' consists of three phonemes: the initial "th" sound, the "r" sound, and a vowel sound. The phonemes in this and many other English words do not always correspond directly to the letters used to spell them (English [[orthography]] is not as strongly [[phonemic orthography|phonemic]] as that of many other languages). The number and distribution of phonemes in English vary from dialect to dialect, and also depend on the interpretation of the individual researcher. The number of consonant phonemes is generally put at 24 (or slightly more). The number of vowels is subject to greater variation; in the system presented on this page there are 20 vowel phonemes in [[Received Pronunciation]], 14–16 in [[General American]] and 20–21 in Australian English {{citation needed|date=November 2018}}. The pronunciation keys used in dictionaries generally contain a slightly greater number of symbols than this, to take account of certain sounds used in foreign words and certain noticeable distinctions that may not be—strictly speaking—phonemic. === Consonants === The following table shows the 24 consonant phonemes found in most dialects of English, in addition to {{IPA|/x/}}, whose distribution is more limited. [[Fortis and lenis|Fortis]] consonants are always [[voicelessness|voiceless]], [[Aspirated consonant|aspirated]] in [[syllable onset]] (except in clusters beginning with {{IPA|/s/}}), and sometimes also [[Glottalization|glottalized]] to an extent in [[syllable coda]] (most likely to occur with {{IPA|/t/}}, see [[T-glottalization]]), while lenis consonants are always [[unaspirated consonant|unaspirated]] and un-glottalized, and generally partially or fully [[voice (phonetics)|voiced]]. The alveolars are usually [[Apical consonant|apical]], i.e. pronounced with the tip of the tongue touching or approaching the roof of the mouth, though some speakers produce them [[Laminal consonant|laminally]], i.e. with the blade of the tongue.{{sfnp|Rogers|2014|p=20}} {|class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" ! colspan="2" | ! [[Labial consonant|Labial]] ! [[Dental consonant|Dental]] ! [[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ! [[postalveolar consonant|Post-
alveolar]] ! [[palatal consonant|Palatal]] ! [[Velar consonant|Velar]] ! [[Glottal consonant|Glottal]] |- ! colspan="2" | [[Nasal consonant|Nasal]] | {{IPA link|m}}1 | | {{IPA link|n}}1 | | | {{IPA link|ŋ}} | |- ! rowspan="2" | [[Plosive]]/
[[affricate]] ! {{small|[[Fortis and lenis|fortis]]}} | {{IPA link|p}} | | {{IPA link|t}} | {{IPA link|t͡ʃ}} | | {{IPA link|k}} | |- ! {{small|[[Fortis and lenis|lenis]]}} | {{IPA link|b}} | | {{IPA link|d}} | {{IPA link|d͡ʒ}} | | {{IPA link|ɡ}} | |- ! rowspan="2" | [[Fricative]] ! {{small|fortis}} | {{IPA link|f}} | {{IPA link|θ}} | {{IPA link|s}} | {{IPA link|ʃ}} | | {{IPA link|x}}2 | rowspan="2" | {{IPA link|h}} |- ! {{small|lenis}} | {{IPA link|v}} | {{IPA link|ð}} | {{IPA link|z}} | {{IPA link|ʒ}} | | |- ! colspan="2" | [[Approximant]] | | | {{IPA link|l}}1 | {{IPA link|ɹ|r}}5 | {{IPA link|j}}4 | {{IPA link|w}}3 | |} # Most varieties of English have [[syllabic consonant]]s in some words, principally {{IPA|[l̩, m̩, n̩]}}, for example at the end of ''bottle'', ''rhythm'' and ''button''. In such cases, no phonetic vowel is pronounced between the last two consonants, and the last consonant forms a [[syllable]] on its own. Syllabic consonants are generally transcribed with a vertical line under the consonant letter, so that phonetic transcription of ''bottle'' would be {{IPA|[ˈbɒtl̩]}}, {{IPA|[ˈbɑɾl̩]}}, or {{IPA|[ˈbɔɾl̩]}} in {{abbr|RP|Received Pronunciation}}, {{abbr|GA|General American}}, and Australian respectively, and for ''button'' {{IPA|[ˈbʌʔn̩]}}. In theory, such consonants could be analyzed as individual phonemes. However, this would add several extra consonant phonemes to the inventory for English,{{sfnp|Roach|2009|pp=100–1}} and phonologists prefer to identify syllabic nasals and [[liquid consonant|liquids]] phonemically as {{IPA|/ə[[consonant|C]]/}}.{{sfnp|Kreidler|2004|p=84}}{{sfnp|Wells|1982|p=55}} Thus ''button'' is phonemically {{IPA|/ˈbʌtən/}} or {{IPA|/ˈbɐtən/}} and ''bottle'' is phonemically {{IPA|/ˈbɒtəl/}}, {{IPA|/ˈbɑtəl/}}, or {{IPA|/ˈbɔtəl/}}. # The [[voiceless velar fricative]] {{IPA|/x/}} is mainly used in [[Hiberno-English|Hiberno-]], [[Scottish English|Scottish]], [[South African English|South African]] and [[Welsh English]]; words with {{IPA|/x/}} in Scottish accents tend to be pronounced with {{IPA|/k/}} in other dialects. The velar fricative sometimes appears in recent [[loanword]]s such as ''chutzpah''. Under the influence of [[Welsh language|Welsh]] and [[Afrikaans]], the actual phonetic realization of {{IPA|/x/}} in Welsh English and White South African English is uvular {{IPAblink|χ}}, rather than velar {{IPAblink|x}}.{{sfnp|Wells|1982|pp=389, 619}}{{sfnp|Tench|1990|p=132}}{{sfnp|Bowerman|2004|p=939}} Dialects do not necessarily agree on the exact words in which {{IPA|/x/}} appears; for instance, in Welsh English it appears in loanwords from Welsh (such as ''[[Amlwch]]'' {{IPA|/ˈæmlʊx/}}), whereas in White South African English it appears only in loanwords from Afrikaans or [[Xhosa language|Xhosa]] (such as ''gogga'' {{IPA|/ˈxɒxə/}} 'insect').{{sfnp|Wells|1982|pp=389, 619}}{{sfnp|Bowerman|2004|p=939}} # In some conservative accents in Scotland, Ireland, the southern United States, and New England, the digraph {{angbr|wh}} in words like ''which'' and ''whine'' represents a voiceless ''w'' sound {{IPA|[ʍ]}}, a [[voiceless labio-velar approximant|voiceless labiovelar fricative]]{{sfnp|Gimson|2008|p=230}}{{sfnp|McMahon|2002|p=31}}{{sfnp|Giegerich|1992|p=36}} or [[voiceless labio-velar approximant|approximant]],{{sfnp|Ladefoged|2006|p=68}} which contrasts with the voiced ''w'' of ''witch'' and ''wine''. In most dialects, this sound is lost, and is pronounced as a voiced ''w'' (the [[Wine–whine merger|''wine''–''whine'' merger]]). Phonemically this sound is analysed as a consonant cluster {{IPA|/hw/}}, rather than as a separate phoneme {{IPA|*/ʍ/}}. Thus ''which'' and ''whine'' are transcribed phonemically as {{IPA|/hwɪtʃ/}} and {{IPA|/hwaɪn/}}. This does not mean that such speakers actually pronounce {{IPA|[h]}} followed by {{IPA|[w]}}: the phonemic transcription {{IPA|/hw/}} is simply a convenient way of representing a single sound {{IPA|[ʍ]}} without analysing such dialects as having an extra phoneme.{{sfnp|Roach|2009|p=43}} # Similarly, the sound at the beginning of ''huge'' in most accents{{verification needed|date=January 2017}} is a [[voiceless palatal fricative]] {{IPA|[ç]}}, but this is analysed phonemically as the consonant cluster {{IPA|/hj/}} so that ''huge'' is transcribed {{IPA|/hjuːdʒ/}}. As with {{IPA|/hw/}}, this does not mean that speakers pronounce {{IPA|[h]}} followed by {{IPA|[j]}}; the phonemic transcription {{IPA|/hj/}} is simply a convenient way of representing the single sound {{IPA|[ç]}}.{{sfnp|Roach|2009|p=43}} The [[yod-dropping]] found in [[Norfolk dialect]] means that the traditional Norfolk pronunciation of ''huge'' is {{IPA|[hʊudʒ]}} and not {{IPA|[çuːdʒ]}}. # This phoneme is conventionally transcribed with the basic Latin letter {{angbr|r}} (the IPA symbol for the [[alveolar trill]]), even though its pronunciation is usually a [[postalveolar approximant]] {{IPA|[ɹ̠]}}. The trill does exist but it is rare, found only in [[Scottish English|Scottish]] dialects and sporadically in [[Received Pronunciation]] preceding a stressed vowel in highly emphatic speech or when placing special emphasis on a word. See [[Pronunciation of English /r/]]. # The [[postalveolar consonant]]s {{IPA|/tʃ, dʒ, ʃ, ʒ, r/}} are also often slightly [[Labialization|labialized]]: {{IPA|[tʃʷ dʒʷ ʃʷ ʒʷ ɹ̠ʷ]}}. ====Consonant examples==== The following table shows typical examples of the occurrence of the above consonant phonemes in words. {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="2" | [[Fortis and lenis|Fortis]] ! colspan="2" | [[Fortis and lenis|Lenis]] |- | {{IPAslink|p}} || '''p'''it | {{IPAslink|b}} || '''b'''it |- | {{IPAslink|t}} || '''t'''in | {{IPAslink|d}} || '''d'''in |- | {{IPAslink|k}} || '''c'''ut | {{IPAslink|ɡ}} || '''g'''ut |- | {{IPAslink|tʃ}} || '''ch'''eap | {{IPAslink|dʒ}} || '''j'''eep |- | {{IPAslink|f}} || '''f'''at | {{IPAslink|v}} || '''v'''at |- | {{IPAslink|θ}} || '''th'''igh | {{IPAslink|ð}} || '''th'''y |- | {{IPAslink|s}} || '''s'''ap | {{IPAslink|z}} || '''z'''ap |- | {{IPAslink|ʃ}} || dilu'''ti'''on | {{IPAslink|ʒ}} || delu'''si'''on |- | {{IPAslink|x}} || lo'''ch''' | colspan="2" | |- | {{IPAslink|h}} || '''h'''am | colspan="2" | |- | colspan="2" | | {{IPAslink|m}} || '''m'''ap |- | colspan="2" | | {{IPAslink|n}} || thi'''n''' |- | colspan="2" | | {{IPAslink|ŋ}} || thi'''ng''' |- | colspan="2" | | {{IPAslink|j}} || '''y'''es |- | colspan="2" | | {{IPAslink|w}} || '''w'''e |- | colspan="2" | | {{IPAslink|ɹ̠|r}} || '''r'''un |- | colspan="2" | | {{IPAslink|l}} || '''l'''eft |} ====Sonorants==== {{See also|Pronunciation of English /r/}} * The pronunciation of {{IPA|/l/}} varies by dialect: ** Received Pronunciation has two main allophones of {{IPA|/l/}}: the clear or plain {{IPA|[l]}}, and the dark or [[velarization|velarized]] {{IPA|[ɫ]}}. The clear variant is used before vowels when they are in the same syllable, and the dark variant when the {{IPA|/l/}} precedes a consonant or is in syllable-final position before silence. ** In South Wales, Ireland, and the Caribbean, {{IPA|/l/}} is often always clear, and in North Wales, Scotland, Australia, and New Zealand it is always dark. ** In General American and Canada, {{IPA|/l/}} is generally dark, but to varying degrees: before stressed vowels it is neutral or only slightly velarized.{{sfnp|Wells|1982|p=490}} In southern U.S. accents it is noticeably clear between vowels, and in some other positions.{{sfnp|Wells|1982|p=550}} ** In urban accents of Southern England, as well as New Zealand and some parts of the United States, {{IPA|/l/}} can be pronounced as an approximant or [[semivowel]] ({{IPA|[w], [o], [ʊ]}}) at the end of a syllable ([[l-vocalization|''l''-vocalization]]). * Depending on dialect, {{IPA|/r/}} has at least the following allophones in varieties of English around the world: ** [[postalveolar approximant]] {{IPA|[ɹ̠]}} (the most common realization of the {{IPA|/r/}} phoneme, occurring in most dialects, RP and General American included) ** [[retroflex approximant]] {{IPA|[ɻ]}} (occurs in most Irish dialects and some American dialects) ** [[labiodental approximant]] {{IPA|[ʋ]}} (occurs in south-east England and some London accents; known as [[R-labialization|''r''-labialization]]) ** [[alveolar flap]] {{IPA|[ɾ]}} (occurs in most Scottish and some South African dialects, some conservative dialects in England and Ireland; not to be confused with [[flapping]] of {{IPA|/t/}} and {{IPA|/d/}}) ** [[alveolar trill]] {{IPA|[r]}} (occurs in some very conservative Scottish dialects) ** [[voiced uvular fricative]] {{IPA|[ʁ]}} (occurs in northern Northumbria, largely disappeared; known as the [[Northumbrian burr]]) * In most dialects {{IPA|/r/}} is [[labialized]] {{IPA|[ɹ̠ʷ]}} in many positions, as in ''reed'' {{IPA|[ɹ̠ʷiːd]}} and ''tree'' {{IPA|[tɹ̠̊ʷiː]}}; in the latter case, the {{IPA|/t/}} may be slightly labialized as well.{{sfnp|Ladefoged|2001|p=55}} * In some [[Rhoticity in English|rhotic accents]], such as General American, {{IPA|/r/}} when not followed by a vowel is realized as an [[r-colored vowel|r-coloring]] of the preceding vowel or its coda: ''nurse'' {{IPA|[ˈnɚs]}}, ''butter'' {{IPA|[ˈbʌtɚ]}}. * The distinctions between the nasals are [[Phoneme#Neutralization|neutralized]] in some environments. For example, before a final {{IPA|/p/}}, {{IPA|/t/}} or {{IPA|/k/}} there is nearly always only one nasal sound that can appear in each case: {{IPA|[m]}}, {{IPA|[n]}} or {{IPA|[ŋ]}} respectively (as in the words ''limp'', ''lint'', ''link'' – note that the ''n'' of ''link'' is pronounced {{IPA|[ŋ]}}). This effect can even occur across syllable or word boundaries, particularly in stressed syllables: ''synchrony'' is pronounced {{IPA|[ˈsɪŋkɹəni]}} whereas ''synchronic'' may be pronounced either as {{IPA|[sɪŋˈkɹɒnɪk]}} or as {{IPA|[sɪnˈkɹɒnɪk]}}. For other possible syllable-final combinations, see {{slink||Coda}} in the Phonotactics section below. ====Obstruents==== In most dialects, the fortis stops and affricate {{IPA|/p, t, tʃ, k/}} have various different allophones, and are distinguished from the lenis stops and affricate {{IPA|/b, d, dʒ, ɡ/}} by several phonetic features.{{sfnp|Celce-Murcia|Brinton|Goodwin|1996|pp=62–67}} * The allophones of the fortes {{IPA|/p, t, tʃ, k/}} include: ** [[Aspiration (phonetics)|aspirated]] {{IPA|[pʰ, tʰ, kʰ]}} when they occur at the beginning of a word, as in '''''t'''omato'', '''''t'''rip'', or at the beginning of a [[lexical stress|stressed]] syllable in the middle of a word, as in ''po'''t'''ato''. They are unaspirated {{IPA|[p, t, k]}} after {{IPA|/s/}} within the same syllable, as in ''s'''t'''an, s'''p'''an, s'''c'''an'', and at the ends of syllables, as in ''mat'', ''map'', ''mac''.{{sfnp|Roach|2009|pp=26–28}} The voiceless fricatives are always unaspirated, but a notable exception to this are English-speaking areas of Wales, where they are often aspirated.{{sfnp|Wells|1982|p=388}} ** In many accents of English, fortis stops {{IPA|/p, t, k, tʃ/}} are [[Glottalization|glottalized]] in some positions. This may be heard either as a glottal stop preceding the oral closure ("pre-glottalization" or "glottal reinforcement") or as a substitution of the glottal stop {{IPA|[ʔ]}} for the oral stop (glottal replacement). {{IPA|/tʃ/}} can only be pre-glottalized. Pre-glottalization normally occurs in British and American English when the fortis consonant phoneme is followed by another consonant or when the consonant is in final position. Thus ''football'' and ''catching'' are often pronounced {{IPA|[ˈfʊʔtbɔːl]}} and {{IPA|[ˈkæʔtʃɪŋ]}}, respectively. Glottal replacement often happens in cases such as those just given, so that ''football'' is frequently pronounced {{IPA|[ˈfʊʔbɔːl]}}. In addition, however, glottal replacement is increasingly common in British English when {{IPA|/t/}} occurs between vowels if the preceding vowel is stressed; thus ''getting better'' is often pronounced by younger speakers as {{IPA|[ˈɡeʔɪŋ ˌbeʔə]}}.{{sfnp|Gimson|2008|pp=179–180}} Such [[t-glottalization|''t''-glottalization]] also occurs in many British regional accents, including [[Cockney English|Cockney]], where it can also occur at the end of words, and where {{IPA|/p/}} and {{IPA|/k/}} are sometimes treated the same way.{{sfnp|Wells|1982|p=323}} * Among stops, both fortes and lenes: ** May have [[no audible release]] {{IPA|[p̚, b̚, t̚, d̚, k̚, ɡ̚]}} in the word-final position.{{sfnp|Celce-Murcia|Brinton|Goodwin|1996|p=64}}{{sfnp|Gimson|2014|pp=173–182}} These allophones are more common in North America than Great Britain.{{sfnp|Celce-Murcia|Brinton|Goodwin|1996|p=64}} ** Always have a 'masked release' before another plosive or affricate (as in ''ru'''bb'''ed'' {{IPA|[ˈrʌˑb̚d̥]}}), i.e. the release of the first stop is made after the closure of the second stop. This also applies when the following stop is [[Homorganic consonants|homorganic]] (articulated in the same place), as in ''to'''p p'''layer''.{{sfnp|Gimson|2014|pp=170 and 173–182}} A notable exception to this is [[Welsh English]], where stops are usually released in this environment.{{sfnp|Wells|1982|p=388}} ** The affricates {{IPA|/tʃ, dʒ/}} have a mandatory fricative release in all environments.{{sfnp|Gimson|2014|p=190}} * Very often in the United States and Canada, and less frequently in Australia{{Harvnb|Trudgill|Hannah|2002|p=18}} and New Zealand,{{Harvnb|Trudgill|Hannah|2002|p=25}} both {{IPA|/t/ and /d/}} can be [[flapping|pronounced as a voiced flap]] {{IPA|[ɾ]}} in certain positions: when they come between a preceding stressed vowel (possibly with intervening {{IPA|/r/}}) and precede an unstressed vowel or [[syllabic consonant|syllabic]] {{IPA|/l/}}. Examples include ''wa'''t'''er'', ''bo'''tt'''le'', ''pe'''t'''al'', ''pe'''dd'''le'' (the last two words sound alike when flapped). The flap may even appear at word boundaries, as in ''pu'''t''' it on''. When the combination {{IPA|/nt/}} appears in such positions, some American speakers pronounce it as a [[nasalization|nasalized]] flap that may become indistinguishable from {{IPA|/n/}}, so ''winter'' {{IPA|[ˈwɪɾ̃ɚ]}} may be pronounced similarly or identically to ''winner'' {{IPA|[ˈwɪnɚ]}}.Mojsin, Lisa (2009), ''Mastering the American Accent'', Barron’s Education Series, Inc., p. 36. "The t after n is often silent in American pronunciation. Instead of saying internet Americans will frequently say 'innernet.' This is fairly standard speech and is not considered overly casual or sloppy speech." *[[Yod-coalescence]] is a process that [[Palatalization (sound change)|palatalizes]] the [[Consonant cluster|clusters]] {{IPA|/dj/}}, {{IPA|/tj/}}, {{IPA|/sj/}} and {{IPA|/zj/}} into {{IPA|[dʒ]}}, {{IPA|[tʃ]}}, {{IPA|[ʃ]}} and {{IPA|[ʒ]}} respectively, frequently occurring with clusters that would be considered to span a syllable boundary.Wyld, H.C., A History of Modern Colloquial English, Blackwell 1936, cited in {{harvp|Wells|1982|p=262}}. **Yod-coalescence in stressed syllables, such as in ''tune'' and ''dune'', occurs in [[Australian English phonology|Australian]], [[Cockney#Cockney speech|Cockney]], [[Estuary English]], [[Hiberno-English]] (some speakers), [[Newfoundland English]], [[South African English]], and to a certain extent in [[New Zealand English]] and [[Scottish English]] (many speakers). This can lead to additional homophony; for instance, ''dew'' and ''due'' come to be pronounced the same as ''Jew''.Bauer, L. & Warren, P. [https://books.google.com/books?id=mtd3a-56ysUC&pg=PA596 New Zealand English: phonology] in Schneider, E.W. "A handbook of varieties of English: Phonology, Volume 1", [[Walter de Gruyter|Mouton De Gruyter]], 2005. **In certain varieties—such as [[Australian English]], South African English, and New Zealand English—{{IPA|/sj/}} and {{IPA|/zj/}} in stressed syllables can coalesce into {{IPA|[ʃ]}} and {{IPA|[ʒ]}}, respectively. In Australian English for example, ''assume'' is pronounced {{IPA|[əˈ'''ʃʉ'''ːm]}} by some speakers.{{sfnp|Wells|1982|p=207}} Furthermore, some British, Canadian, American, New Zealand and Australian speakers may change the {{IPA|/s/}} sound to {{IPA|/ʃ/}} before {{IPA|/tr/}},Durian, David (2007) "Getting [ʃ]tronger Every Day?: More on Urbanization and the Socio-geographic Diffusion of (str) in Columbus, OH," University of Pennsylvania Working Papers in Linguistics: Vol. 13: Iss. 2, Article 6 so that a word having a cluster of "str" like in '''''st'''rewed'' would be pronounced {{IPA|[ʃtʃruːd]}}.{{cite book|author=Jennifer Hay|title=New Zealand English|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=--eqBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA37|date=6 March 2008|publisher=Edinburgh University Press|isbn=978-0-7486-3088-2|pages=37–}} According to author Wayne P. Lawrence, "this [[Phonological change|phonemic change]] seems to be neither dialectal nor regional." Lawrence, Wayne P. (2000) "Assimilation at a Distance," American Speech Vol. 75: Iss. 1: 82-87; doi:10.1215/00031283-75-1-82 ===Vowels=== English has a particularly large number of vowel phonemes, and on top of that the [[vowel]]s of English differ considerably between dialects. Because of this, corresponding vowels may be transcribed with various symbols depending on the dialect under consideration. When considering English as a whole, [[lexical set]]s are often used, each named by a word containing the vowel or vowels in question. For example, the {{sc2|LOT}} set consists of words which, like ''lot'', have {{IPA|/ɒ/}} in [[Received Pronunciation]] and {{IPA|/ɑ/}} in [[General American]]. The "{{sc2|LOT}} vowel" then refers to the vowel that appears in those words in whichever dialect is being considered, or (at a greater level of [[abstraction]]) to a [[diaphoneme]], which represents this interdialectal correspondence. A commonly used system of lexical sets, devised by [[John C. Wells]], is presented below; for each set, the corresponding phonemes are given for RP and General American, using the notation that will be used on this page. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center; float: left; margin-right: 1em;" |+ class="nowrap" | Full monophthongs ! {{abbr|LS|Wells standard lexical set}} ! {{abbr|RP|Received Pronunciation}} ! {{abbr|GA|General American}} |- | {{sc2|TR'''A'''P}} | colspan="2" | {{IPA link|æ}} |- | {{sc2|B'''A'''TH}} | rowspan="2" | {{IPA link|ɑː}} | {{IPA link|æ}} |- | {{sc2|P'''A'''LM}} | rowspan="2" | {{IPA link|ɑ}} |- | {{sc2|L'''O'''T}} | rowspan="2" | {{IPA link|ɒ}} |- | {{sc2|CL'''O'''TH}} | rowspan="2" | {{IPA link|ɔ}}, {{IPA link|ɑ}} |- | {{sc2|TH'''OUGH'''T}} | {{IPA link|ɔ̝|ɔː}} |- | {{sc2|K'''I'''T}} | colspan="2" | {{IPA link|ɪ}} |- | {{sc2|DR'''E'''SS}} | {{IPA link|e̞|e}} | {{IPA link|ɛ}} |- | {{sc2|STR'''U'''T}} | colspan="2" | {{IPA link|ɐ|ʌ}} |- | {{sc2|F'''OO'''T}} | colspan="2" | {{IPA link|ʊ}} |} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center; float: left; margin-right: 1em;" |+ class="nowrap" | Potential
diphthongs{{sfnp|Wells|1982|pp=140, 147, 299}} ! {{abbr|LS|Wells standard lexical set}} ! {{abbr|RP|Received Pronunciation}} ! {{abbr|GA|General American}} |- | {{sc2|F'''A'''CE}} | colspan="2" | {{IPA|eɪ}} |- | {{sc2|G'''OA'''T}} | {{IPA|əʊ}} | {{IPA|oʊ}} |- | {{sc2|FL'''EE'''CE}} | {{IPA link|iː}} | {{IPA link|i}} |- | {{sc2|G'''OO'''SE}} | {{IPA link|uː}} | {{IPA link|u}} |} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center; float: left; margin-right: 1em;" |+ class="nowrap" | Full diphthongs ! {{abbr|LS|Wells standard lexical set}} ! {{abbr|RP|Received Pronunciation}} ! {{abbr|GA|General American}} |- | {{sc2|PR'''I'''CE}} | colspan="2" | {{IPA|aɪ}} |- | {{sc2|CH'''OI'''CE}} | colspan="2" | {{IPA|ɔɪ}} |- | {{sc2|M'''OU'''TH}} | colspan="2" | {{IPA|aʊ}} |} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center; float: left; margin-right: 1em;" |+ class="nowrap" | Pre-R vowels ! {{abbr|LS|Wells standard lexical set}} ! {{abbr|RP|Received Pronunciation}} ! {{abbr|GA|General American}} |- | {{sc2|N'''UR'''SE}} | {{IPA|ɜː(r)}} | {{IPA|ɜr}} |- | {{sc2|ST'''AR'''T}} | {{IPA|ɑː(r)}} | {{IPA|ɑr}} |- | {{sc2|N'''OR'''TH}} | rowspan="2" | {{IPA|ɔː(r)}} | {{IPA|ɔr}} |- | {{sc2|F'''OR'''CE}} | {{IPA|ɔr}}, {{IPA|oʊr}} |- | {{sc2|N'''EAR'''}} | {{IPA|ɪə(r)}} | {{IPA|ɪr}} |- | {{sc2|SQU'''ARE'''}} | {{IPA|eə(r)}} | {{IPA|ɛr}} |- | {{sc2|C'''URE'''}} | {{IPA|ʊə(r)}} | {{IPA|ʊr}} |} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center; float: left;" |+ class="nowrap" | Reduced vowels ! {{abbr|LS|Wells standard lexical set}} ! {{abbr|RP|Received Pronunciation}} ! {{abbr|GA|General American}} |- | {{sc2|COMM'''A'''}} | colspan="2" | {{IPA link|ə}} |- | {{sc2|LETT'''ER'''}} | {{IPA|ə(r)}} | {{IPA|ər}} |- | {{sc2|HAPP'''Y'''}} | colspan="2" | {{IPA link|i}} |} {{clear}} For a table that shows the pronunciations of these vowels in a wider range of English dialects, see [[IPA chart for English dialects]]. The following tables show the vowel phonemes of three standard varieties of English. The notation system used here for Received Pronunciation (RP) is fairly standard; the others less so. The feature descriptions given here (front, close, etc.) are abstracted somewhat; the actual pronunciations of these vowels are somewhat more accurately conveyed by the [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] symbols used (see [[Vowel]] for a chart indicating the meanings of these symbols; though note also the points listed below the following tables). {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center; float: left; margin-right: 1em;" |+ Received Pronunciation{{sfnp|Roach|2004|p=242}} ! rowspan="2" | ! colspan="2" |[[Front vowel|Front]] ! colspan="2" |[[Central vowel|Central]] ! colspan="2" |[[Back vowel|Back]] |- ! {{small|short}} ! {{small|long}} ! {{small|short}} ! {{small|long}} ! {{small|short}} ! {{small|long}} |- ! [[Diphthong]]s | colspan="6" | {{IPA|æɪ   ɑe   oɪ   æɔ   əʉ}}
{{IPA|ɪə   (ʊə)}} |} {{clear}} # Although the notation {{IPA|/ʌ/}} is used for the vowel of {{sc2|STRUT}} in RP, the actual pronunciation is closer to a [[near-open central unrounded vowel]] {{IPA|[ɐ]}}. The symbol {{angle bracket|{{IPA|ʌ}}}} continues to be used for reasons of tradition (it was historically a back vowel) and because it is still back in other varieties.{{sfnp|Roca|Johnson|1999|p=135}} # General American lacks a truly contrastive {{sc2|NURSE}} vowel, so pairs like ''forward'' vs. ''foreword'' (distinguished in RP as {{IPA|/ˈfɔːwəd/}} and {{IPA|/ˈfɔːwɜːd/}}, respectively) are most typically homophonous as {{IPA|[ˈfɔɹwɚd]}}. Also, {{IPA|[ʌ]}} (stressed) and {{IPA|[ə]}} (unstressed) may be considered allophones of a single phoneme in General American.{{sfnp|Wells|1982|pp=121, 132}} # Although the notation {{IPA|/eɪ oʊ/}} are used for the vowels of {{sc2|FACE}} and {{sc2|GOAT}} respectively in General American, they are analysed as phonemic monophthongs and frequently transcribed as {{IPA|/e o/}} in the literature. # Many North American speakers do not distinguish {{IPA|/ɔ/}} from {{IPA|/ɑ/}} and merge them into {{IPA|/ɑ/}}, except before {{IPA|/r/}} (see [[Cot–caught merger|''cot–caught'' merger]]). The differences between these tables can be explained as follows: * General American lacks a phoneme corresponding to RP {{IPA|/ɒ/}} ({{sc2|LOT}}, {{sc2|CLOTH}}), instead using {{IPA|/ɑ/}} in the {{sc2|LOT}} words and generally {{IPA|/ɔ/}} in the {{sc2|CLOTH}} words. In a few North American accents, namely in [[Eastern New England English|Eastern New England]] ([[Boston]]), [[Western Pennsylvania English|Western Pennsylvania]] ([[Pittsburgh]]), and to some degree in [[Pacific Northwest English|Pacific Northwest]] ([[Seattle]], [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]]) and Eastern [[Canadian English]], {{sc2|LOT}} words do not have the vowel of {{sc2|PALM}} (the [[father–bother merger|''father''–''bother'' merger]] has not occurred) but instead merge with {{sc2|CLOTH/THOUGHT}}.{{sfnp|Wells|1982|pp=473–474}}{{cite book|last1=Labov|first1=William|last2=Ash|first2=Sharon|last3=Boberg|first3=Charles|title=The Atlas of North American English: Phonetics, Phonology and Sound Change|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tsPvynQtlMoC&pg=PA171|year=2006|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|isbn=978-3-11-020683-8|pages=13, 171–173}}{{cite book|last=Woods|first=Howard B.|editor-last=Clarke|editor-first=Sandra|title=Focus on Canada|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zkV4e1b8q_oC&pg=PA170|year=1993|publisher=John Benjamins Publishing|isbn=90-272-7681-1|pages=170–171|chapter=A synchronic study of English spoken in Ottawa: Is Canadian becoming more American?}}{{cite book|last1=Kiefte|first1=Michael|last2=Kay-Raining Bird|first2=Elizabeth|title=The Lesser-Known Varieties of English: An Introduction|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-TGSgT2SyH0C&pg=PA63|year=2010|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-139-48741-2|pages=63–64, 67|chapter=Canadian Maritime English}} * RP transcriptions use {{IPA|/e/}} rather than {{IPA|/ɛ/}} largely for convenience and historical tradition; it does not necessarily represent a different sound from the General American phoneme, although the RP vowel may be described as somewhat less open than the American one.{{sfnp|Wells|1982|p=128}} * The different notations used for the vowel of {{sc2|GOAT}} in RP and General American ({{IPA|/əʊ/}} and {{IPA|/oʊ/}}) reflect a difference in the most common phonetic realizations of that vowel. * The triphthongs given in the RP table are usually regarded as sequences of two phonemes (a diphthong plus {{IPA|/ə/}}); however, in RP, these sequences frequently undergo [[smoothing (phonetics)|smoothing]] into single diphthongs or even monophthongs. * The different notations used here for some of the Australian vowels reflect the phonetic realization of those vowels in Australian: a central {{IPA|[ʉː]}} rather than {{IPA|[uː]}} in {{sc2|GOOSE}}, a more closed {{IPA|[e]}} rather than {{IPA|[ɛ]}} in {{sc2|DRESS}}, an open-mid {{IPA|[ɔ]}} rather than traditional RP's {{IPA|[ɒ]}} in {{sc2|LOT}} and {{sc2|CLOTH}}, a close-mid {{IPA|[oː]}} rather than mid {{IPA|[ɔː]}} in {{sc2|THOUGHT}}, {{sc2|NORTH}} and {{sc2|FORCE}} (here the difference lies almost only in transcription rather than pronunciation), an opener {{IPA|[ɐ]}} rather than somewhat closer {{IPA|[ʌ]}} in {{sc2|STRUT}}, a fronted {{IPA|[ɐː]}} rather than {{IPA|[ɑː]}} in {{sc2|CALM}} and {{sc2|START}}, and somewhat different pronunciations of most of the diphthongs. Note that central {{IPA|[ʉː]}} in {{sc2|GOOSE}} and open-mid {{IPA|[ɔ]}} in {{sc2|LOT}} are possible realizations in modern RP; in the case of the latter vowel, it is even more common than the traditional open {{IPA|[ɒ]}}.{{sfnp|Gimson|2014|pp=126 and 133}} * The Australian monophthong {{IPA|/eː/}} corresponds to the RP diphthong {{IPA|/eə/}} ({{sc2|SQUARE}}). * Australian has the [[bad–lad split|''bad''–''lad'' split]], with distinctive short and long variants in various words of the {{sc2|TRAP}} set: a long phoneme {{IPA|/æː/}} in words like ''bad'' contrasts with a short {{IPA|/æ/}} in words like ''lad''. (A similar split is found in the accents of some speakers in southern England.) * The vowel {{IPA|/ʊə/}} is often omitted from descriptions of Australian, as for most speakers it has split into the long monophthong {{IPA|/oː/}} (e.g. ''poor'', ''sure'') or the sequence {{IPA|/ʉːə/}} (e.g. ''cure'', ''lure'').{{Cite news|first1=Felicity|last1=Cox|first2=Sallyanne|last2=Palethorpe|title=Illustrations of the IPA: Australian English|journal=Journal of the International Phonetic Association|year=2007|volume=37|number=3|pages=341–350}} Other points to be noted are these: * The vowel {{IPA|/æ/}} is coming to be pronounced more open (approaching {{IPA|[a]}}) by many modern RP speakers. In American speech, however, there is a tendency for it to become more closed, tenser and even diphthongized (to something like {{IPA|[eə]}}), particularly in certain environments, such as before a [[nasal consonant]].{{sfnp|Wells|1982|p=129}} Some American accents, for example those of [[New York City]], [[Philadelphia]] and [[Baltimore]], make a marginal phonemic distinction between {{IPA|/æ/}} and {{IPA|/eə/}}, although the two occur largely in mutually exclusive environments. See [[:/æ/ raising]]. * A significant number of words (the {{sc2|BATH}} group) have {{IPA|/æ/}} in General American, but {{IPA|/ɑː/}} in RP (and mostly {{IPA|/ɐː/}} in Australian). * In General American and Canadian (which are [[Rhotic and non-rhotic accents|rhotic accents]], where {{IPA|/r/}} is pronounced in positions where it does not precede a vowel), many of the vowels can be [[R-colored vowel|r-colored]] by way of realization of a following {{IPA|/r/}}. This is often transcribed phonetically using a vowel symbol with an added retroflexion [[diacritic]] {{IPA |[ ˞ ]}}; thus the symbol {{IPA|[ɚ]}} has been created for an r-colored [[schwa]] (sometimes called schwar) as in {{sc2|LETT'''ER'''}}, and the vowel of {{sc2|START}} can be modified to make {{IPA|[ɑ˞]}} so that the word ''start'' may be transcribed {{IPA|[stɑ˞t]}}. Alternatively, the {{sc2|START}} vowel might be written {{IPA|[stɑɚt]}} to indicate an r-colored offglide. The vowel of {{sc2|NURSE}} is generally always r-colored in these dialects, and this can be written {{IPA|[ɚ]}} (or as a syllabic {{IPA|[ɹ̩]}}). * In modern RP and other dialects, many words from the {{sc2|CURE}} group are coming to be pronounced by an increasing number of speakers with the {{sc2|NORTH}} vowel (so ''sure'' is often pronounced like ''shore''). Also the RP vowels {{IPA|/ɛə/}} and {{IPA|/ʊə/}} may be monophthongized to {{IPA|[ɛː]}} and {{IPA|[oː]}} respectively.{{sfnp|Roach|2004|p=240}} * The vowels of {{sc2|FLEECE}} and {{sc2|GOOSE}} are commonly pronounced as narrow diphthongs, approaching {{IPA|[ɪi]}} and {{IPA|[ʊu]}}, in RP. Near-RP speakers may have particularly marked diphthongization of the type {{IPA|[əi]}} and {{IPA|[əu ~ əʉ]}}, respectively. In General American, the pronunciation varies between a monophthong and a diphthong.{{sfnp|Wells|1982|pp=140, 147, 299}} ====Allophones of vowels==== Listed here are some of the significant cases of [[allophony]] of vowels found within standard English dialects. *Vowels are shortened when followed in a syllable by a voiceless ([[fortis consonant|fortis]]) consonant.{{cite book|last1=Collins|first1=Beverley|last2=Mees|first2=Inger|title=Practical Phonetics and Phonology|date=2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9780415506496|page=58|edition=3rd}} This is known as [[Clipping (phonetics)|''pre-fortis clipping'']]. Thus in the following word pairs the first item has a shortened vowel while the second has a normal length vowel: 'right' {{IPA|/raɪt/}} - 'ride' {{IPA|/raɪd/}}; 'face' {{IPA|/feɪs/}} - 'phase' {{IPA|/feɪz/}}; 'advice' {{IPA|/ədvaɪs/}} - 'advise' {{IPA|/ədvaɪz/}}. * In many accents of English, [[tenseness|tense]] vowels undergo [[vowel breaking|breaking]] before {{IPA|/l/}}, resulting in pronunciations like {{IPA|[pʰiəɫ]}} for ''peel'', {{IPA|[pʰuəɫ]}} for ''pool'', {{IPA|[pʰeəɫ]}} for ''pail'', and {{IPA|[pʰoəɫ]}} for ''pole''.{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} * In RP, the vowel {{IPA|/əʊ/}} may be pronounced more back, as {{IPA|[ɒʊ]}}, before syllable-final {{IPA|/l/}}, as in ''goal''. In Australian English the vowel {{IPA|/əʉ/}} is similarly backed to {{IPA|[ɔʊ]}} before {{IPA|/l/}}. A similar phenomenon may occur in [[Southern American English]].{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} * The vowel {{IPA|/ə/}} is often pronounced {{IPA|[ɐ]}} in open syllables.{{sfnp|Gimson|2008|p=132}} * The {{sc2|PRICE}} and {{sc2|MOUTH}} diphthongs may be pronounced with a less open starting point when followed by a [[voiceless]] consonant;{{sfnp|Celce-Murcia|Brinton|Goodwin|1996|p=66}} this is chiefly a feature of Canadian speech ([[Canadian raising]]), but is also found in parts of the United States.{{sfnp|Wells|1982|p=149}} Thus ''writer'' may be distinguished from ''rider'' even when [[flapping]] causes the {{IPA|/t/}} and {{IPA|/d/}} to be pronounced identically. ====Unstressed syllables==== {{hatnote|For more information, see [[Stress and vowel reduction in English]].}} [[Unstressed syllable]]s in English may contain almost any vowel, but in practice vowels in stressed and unstressed syllables tend to use different inventories of phonemes. In particular, long vowels are used less often in unstressed syllables than stressed syllables. Additionally there are certain sounds—characterized by [[central vowel|central]] position and weakness—that are particularly often found as the nuclei of unstressed syllables. These include: * [[schwa]], {{IPA|[ə]}}, as in {{sc2|COMM'''A'''}} and (in non-rhotic dialects) {{sc2|LETT'''ER'''}} ([[Panda–pander merger|''panda''–''pander'' merger]]); also in many other positions such as '''''a'''bout'', ''phot'''o'''graph'', ''padd'''o'''ck'', etc. This sound is essentially restricted to unstressed syllables exclusively. In the approach presented here it is identified as a phoneme {{IPA|/ə/}}, although other analyses do not have a separate phoneme for schwa and regard it as a reduction or neutralization of other vowels in syllables with the lowest degree of stress. * [[r-colored schwa]], {{IPA|[ɚ]}}, as in {{sc2|LETT'''ER'''}} in General American and some other rhotic dialects, which can be identified with the underlying sequence {{IPA|/ər/}}. * [[syllabic consonant]]s: {{IPA|[l̩]}} as in ''bott'''le''''', {{IPA|[n̩]}} as in ''butt'''on''''', {{IPA|[m̩]}} as in ''rhyth'''m'''''. These may be phonemized either as a plain consonant or as a schwa followed by a consonant; for example ''button'' may be represented as {{IPA|/ˈbʌtn̩/}} or {{IPA|/ˈbʌtən/}} (see above under [[#Consonants|Consonants]]). * {{IPA|[ɨ̞]}}, as in ''ros'''e'''s'' and ''mak'''i'''ng''. This can be identified with the phoneme {{IPA|/ɪ/}}, although in unstressed syllables it may be pronounced more centrally, and for some speakers (particularly in Australian and New Zealand and some American English) it is merged with {{IPA|/ə/}} in these syllables ([[weak vowel merger]]). Among speakers who retain the distinction there are many cases where [[free variation]] between {{IPA|/ɪ/}} and {{IPA|/ə/}} is found, as in the second syllable of ''typ'''i'''cal''. (The [[OED]] has recently adopted the symbol {{angbr|ᵻ}} to indicate such cases.) * {{IPA|[ʉ̞]}}, as in ''arg'''u'''ment'', ''t'''o'''day'', for which similar considerations apply as in the case of {{IPA|[ɨ̞]}}. (The symbol {{angbr|ᵿ}} is sometimes used in these cases, similarly to {{angbr|ᵻ}}.) Some speakers may also have a rounded schwa, {{IPA|[ɵ]}}, used in words like ''omission'' {{IPA|[ɵˈmɪʃən]}}.{{sfnp|Bolinger|1986|pp=347-360}} * {{IPA|[i]}}, as in ''happ'''y''''', ''coff'''ee''''', in many dialects (others have {{IPA|[ɪ]}} in this position).{{cite web|last=Lewis|first=J. Windsor|title=HappYland Reconnoitred|url=http://www.yek.me.uk/happyland.html|accessdate=2012-01-01}} The phonemic status of this {{IPA|[i]}} is not easy to establish. Some authors consider it to correspond phonemically with a close front vowel that is neither the vowel of {{sc2|KIT}} nor that of {{sc2|FLEECE}}; it occurs chiefly in contexts where the contrast between these vowels is neutralized,{{sfnp|Kreidler|2004|pp=82–3}}{{sfnp|McCully|2009|pp=123–4}}{{sfnp|Roach|2009|pp=66–8}} implying that it represents an [[archiphoneme]], which may be written {{IPA|/i/}}. Many speakers, however, do have a contrast in pairs of words like ''studied'' and ''studded'' or ''taxis'' and ''taxes''; the contrast may be {{IPA|[i]}} vs. {{IPA|[ɪ]}}, {{IPA|[ɪ]}} vs. {{IPA|[ə]}} or {{IPA|[i]}} vs. {{IPA|[ə]}}, hence some authors consider that the ''happY''-vowel should be identified phonemically either with the vowel of {{sc2|KIT}} or that of {{sc2|FLEECE}}, depending on speaker.{{sfnp|Wells|2014|p=53}} See also [[happy-tensing|''happy''-tensing]]. * {{IPA|[u]}}, as in ''infl'''u'''ence'', ''t'''o''' each''. This is the back rounded counterpart to {{IPA|[i]}} described above; its phonemic status is treated in the same works as cited there. [[Vowel reduction]] in unstressed syllables is a significant feature of English. Syllables of the types listed above often correspond to a syllable containing a different vowel ("full vowel") used in other forms of the same [[morpheme]] where that syllable is stressed. For example, the first ''o'' in ''photograph'', being stressed, is pronounced with the {{sc2|GOAT}} vowel, but in ''photography'', where it is unstressed, it is reduced to schwa. Also, certain common words (''a'', ''an'', ''of'', ''for'', etc.) are pronounced with a schwa when they are unstressed, although they have different vowels when they are in a stressed position (see [[Weak and strong forms in English]]). Some unstressed syllables, however, retain full (unreduced) vowels, i.e. vowels other than those listed above. Examples are the {{IPA|/æ/}} in '''''a'''mbition'' and the {{IPA|/aɪ/}} in ''fin'''i'''te''. Some phonologists regard such syllables as not being fully unstressed (they may describe them as having ''tertiary stress''); some dictionaries have marked such syllables as having [[secondary stress]]. However linguists such as LadefogedPeter Ladefoged (1975 ''etc.'') ''A course in phonetics'' and {{Harvcoltxt|Bolinger|1986}} regard this as a difference purely of vowel quality and not of stress,{{sfnp|Bolinger|1986|p=351}} and thus argue that vowel reduction itself is phonemic in English. Examples of words where vowel reduction seems to be distinctive for some speakers{{sfnp|Bolinger|1986|p=348}} include ''chickar'''ee''''' vs. ''chicor'''y''''' (the latter has the reduced vowel of {{sc2|HAPP'''Y'''}}, whereas the former has the {{sc2|FLEECE}} vowel without reduction), and ''Phar'''aoh''''' vs. ''farr'''ow''''' (both have the {{sc2|GOAT}} vowel, but in the latter word it may reduce to {{IPA|[ɵ]}}). ==Lexical stress== {{main|Stress and vowel reduction in English}} [[Stress (linguistics)|Lexical stress]] is phonemic in English. For example, the noun '''''in'''crease'' and the verb ''in'''crease''''' are distinguished by the positioning of the stress on the first syllable in the former, and on the second syllable in the latter. (See [[initial-stress-derived noun]].) Stressed syllables in English are louder than non-stressed syllables, as well as being longer and having a higher pitch. In traditional approaches, in any English word consisting of more than one [[syllable]], each syllable is ascribed one of three degrees of stress: ''primary'', ''secondary'' or ''unstressed''. Ordinarily, in each such word there will be exactly one syllable with primary stress, possibly one syllable having secondary stress, and the remainder are unstressed. For example, the word ''am'''az'''ing'' has primary stress on the second syllable, while the first and third syllables are unstressed, whereas the word '''''or'''ganiz'''a'''tion'' has primary stress on the fourth syllable, secondary stress on the first, and the second, third and fifth unstressed. This is often shown in pronunciation keys using the [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] symbols for primary and secondary stress (which are ˈ and ˌ respectively), placed before the syllables to which they apply. The two words just given may therefore be represented (in [[Received Pronunciation|RP]]) as {{IPA|/əˈmeɪzɪŋ/}} and {{IPA|/ˌɔːɡənaɪˈzeɪʃən/}}. Some analysts identify an additional level of stress (''tertiary'' stress). This is generally ascribed to syllables that are pronounced with less force than those with secondary stress, but nonetheless contain a "full" or "unreduced" vowel (vowels that are considered to be reduced are listed under {{slink|English phonology|Unstressed syllables}} above). Hence the third syllable of ''organization'', if pronounced with {{IPA|/aɪ/}} as shown above (rather than being reduced to {{IPA|/ɪ/}} or {{IPA|/ə/}}), might be said to have tertiary stress. (The precise identification of secondary and tertiary stress differs between analyses; dictionaries do not generally show tertiary stress, although some have taken the approach of marking all syllables with unreduced vowels as having at least secondary stress.) In some analyses, then, the concept of lexical stress may become conflated with that of vowel reduction. An approach which attempts to separate these two is provided by [[Peter Ladefoged]], who states that it is possible to describe English with only one degree of stress, as long as [[unstressed vowel|unstressed syllables]] are phonemically distinguished for [[vowel reduction]].Ladefoged (1975 ''etc.'') ''[[A course in phonetics]]'' §5.4; (1980) ''Preliminaries to linguistic phonetics'' p. 83 In this approach, the distinction between primary and secondary stress is regarded as a phonetic or prosodic detail rather than a phonemic feature – primary stress is seen as an example of the predictable "tonic" stress that falls on the ''final'' stressed syllable of a [[prosodic unit]]. For more details of this analysis, see [[Stress and vowel reduction in English]]. For stress as a prosodic feature (emphasis of particular words within utterances), see {{slink||Prosodic stress}} below. ==Phonotactics== [[Phonotactics]] is the study of the sequences of phonemes that occur in languages and the sound structures that they form. In this study it is usual to represent consonants in general with the letter C and vowels with the letter V, so that a syllable such as 'be' is described as having CV structure. The [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] symbol used to show a division between syllables is the dot {{IPA|[.]}}. Syllabification is the process of dividing continuous speech into discrete syllables, a process in which the position of a syllable division is not always easy to decide upon. Most languages of the world syllabify {{IPA|CVCV}} and {{IPA|CVCCV}} sequences as {{IPA|/CV.CV/}} and {{IPA|/CVC.CV/}} or {{IPA|/CV.CCV/}}, with consonants preferentially acting as the onset of a syllable containing the following vowel. According to one view, English is unusual in this regard, in that stressed syllables attract following consonants, so that {{IPA|ˈCVCV}} and {{IPA|ˈCVCCV}} syllabify as {{IPA|/ˈCVC.V/}} and {{IPA|/ˈCVCC.V/}}, as long as the consonant cluster {{IPA|CC}} is a possible syllable coda; in addition, {{IPA|/r/}} preferentially syllabifies with the preceding vowel even when both syllables are unstressed, so that {{IPA|CVrV}} occurs as {{IPA|/CVr.V/}}. This is the analysis used in the ''[[Longman Pronunciation Dictionary]]''.{{sfnp|Wells|1990|pp=76–86}} However, this view is not widely accepted, as explained in the following section. ===Syllable structure=== The [[syllable]] structure in English is (C)3V(C)5, with a near maximal example being ''strengths'' ({{IPA|/strɛŋkθs/}}, although it can be pronounced {{IPA|/strɛŋθs/}}).Five-consonant codas are rare, but one occurs in ''angsts'' {{IPA|/æŋksts/}}. See [[list of the longest English words with one syllable]] for further long syllables in English. From the phonetic point of view, the analysis of syllable structures is a complex task: because of widespread occurrences of articulatory overlap, English speakers rarely produce an audible release of individual consonants in consonant clusters.{{sfnp|Zsiga|2003|p=404}} This coarticulation can lead to articulatory gestures that seem very much like deletions or complete assimilations. For example, ''hundred pounds'' may sound like {{IPA|[hʌndɹɪ'''b''' paʊndz]}} and ''jumped back'' (in slow speech, {{IPA|[dʒʌmptbæk]}}) may sound like {{IPA|[dʒʌmpbæk]}}, but X-ray{{sfnp|Browman|Goldstein|1990}} and electropalatographic {{sfnp|Barry|1991}}{{sfnp|Barry|1992}}{{sfnp|Nolan|1992}} studies demonstrate that inaudible and possibly weakened contacts or lingual gestures may still be made. Thus the second {{IPA|/d/}} in ''hundred pounds'' does not entirely assimilate to a labial place of articulation, rather the labial gesture co-occurs with the alveolar one; the "missing" {{IPA|[t]}} in ''jumped back'' may still be articulated, though not heard. Division into syllables is a difficult area, and different theories have been proposed. A widely accepted approach is the maximal onset principle:{{sfnp|Selkirk|1982}} this states that, subject to certain constraints, any consonants in between vowels should be assigned to the following syllable. Thus the word ''leaving'' should be divided {{IPA|/ˈliː.vɪŋ/}} rather than *{{IPA|/ˈliːv.ɪŋ/}}, and ''hasty'' is {{IPA|/ˈheɪ.sti/}} rather than *{{IPA|/ˈheɪs.ti/}} or *{{IPA|/ˈheɪst.i/}}. However, when such a division results in an onset cluster which is not allowed in English, the division must respect this. Thus if the word ''extra'' were divided *{{IPA|/ˈe.kstrə/}} the resulting onset of the second syllable would be {{IPA|/kstr/}}, a cluster which does not occur initially in English. The division {{IPA|/ˈek.strə/}} is therefore preferred. If assigning a consonant or consonants to the following syllable would result in the preceding syllable ending in an unreduced short vowel, this is avoided. Thus the word ''comma'' (in RP) should be divided {{IPA|/ˈkɒm.ə/}} and not *{{IPA|/ˈkɒ.mə/}}, even though the latter division gives the maximal onset to the following syllable. In some cases, no solution is completely satisfactory: for example, in British English (RP) the word ''hurry'' could be divided {{IPA|/ˈhʌ.ri/}} or {{IPA|/ˈhʌr.i/}}, but the former would result in an analysis with a syllable-final {{IPA|/ʌ/}} (which is held to be non-occurring) while the latter would result in a syllable final {{IPA|/r/}} (which is said not to occur in this accent). Some phonologists have suggested a compromise analysis where the consonant in the middle belongs to both syllables, and is described as [[Ambisyllabicity|ambisyllabic]].{{sfnp|Giegerich|1992|p=172}}{{sfnp|Harris|1994|p=198}} In this way, it is possible to suggest an analysis of ''hurry'' which comprises the syllables {{IPA|/hʌr/}} and {{IPA|/ri/}}, the medial {{IPA|/r/}} being ambisyllabic. Where the division coincides with a word boundary, or the boundary between elements of a compound word, it is not usual in the case of dictionaries to insist on the maximal onset principle in a way that divides words in a counter-intuitive way; thus the word ''hardware'' would be divided {{IPA|/ˈhɑː.dweə/}} by the M.O.P., but dictionaries prefer the division {{IPA|/ˈhɑːd.weə/}}.{{sfnp|Gimson|2008|pp=258–9}}{{sfnp|Giegerich|1992|pp=167–70}}{{sfnp|Kreidler|2004|pp=76–8}} In the approach used by the ''[[Longman Pronunciation Dictionary]]'', Wells{{sfnp|Wells|1990|pp=76–86}} claims that consonants syllabify with the preceding rather than following vowel when the preceding vowel is the nucleus of a more salient syllable, with stressed syllables being the most salient, reduced syllables the least, and full unstressed vowels ("secondary stress") intermediate. But there are lexical differences as well, frequently but not exclusively with compound words. For example, in ''dolphin'' and ''selfish,'' Wells argues that the stressed syllable ends in {{IPA|/lf/}}, but in ''shellfish,'' the {{IPA|/f/}} belongs with the following syllable: {{IPA|/ˈdɒlf.ɪn, ˈself.ɪʃ/}} → {{IPA|[ˈdɒlfɪ̈n, ˈselfɪ̈ʃ]}}, but {{IPA|/ˈʃel.fɪʃ/}} → {{IPA|[ˈʃelˑfɪʃ]}}, where the {{IPA|/l/}} is a little longer and the {{IPA|/ɪ/}} is not reduced. Similarly, in ''toe-strap'' Wells argues that the second {{IPA|/t/}} is a full plosive, as usual in syllable onset, whereas in ''toast-rack'' the second {{IPA|/t/}} is in many dialects reduced to the unreleased allophone it takes in syllable codas, or even elided: {{IPA|/ˈtoʊ.stræp/, /ˈtoʊst.ræk/}} → {{IPA|[ˈtoˑʊstɹæp, ˈtoʊs(t̚)ɹæk]}}; likewise ''nitrate'' {{IPA|/ˈnaɪ.treɪt/}} → {{IPA|[ˈnaɪtɹ̥eɪt]}} with a voiceless {{IPA|/r/}} (and for some people an affricated ''tr'' as in ''tree''), vs ''night-rate'' {{IPA|/ˈnaɪt.reɪt/}} → {{IPA|[ˈnaɪt̚ɹeɪt]}} with a voiced {{IPA|/r/}}. Cues of syllable boundaries include aspiration of syllable onsets and (in the US) flapping of coda {{IPA|/t, d/}} ''(a tease'' {{IPA|/ə.ˈtiːz/}} → {{IPA|[əˈtʰiːz]}} vs. ''at ease'' {{IPA|/æt.ˈiːz/}} → {{IPA|[æɾˈiːz]}}), epenthetic stops like {{IPA|[t]}} in syllable codas (''fence'' {{IPA|/ˈfens/}} → {{IPA|[ˈfents]}} but ''inside'' {{IPA|/ɪn.ˈsaɪd/}} → {{IPA|[ɪnˈsaɪd]}}), and r-colored vowels when the {{IPA|/r/}} is in the coda vs. labialization when it is in the onset ''(key-ring'' {{IPA|/ˈkiː.rɪŋ/}} → {{IPA|[ˈkiːɹʷɪŋ]}} but ''fearing'' {{IPA|/ˈfiːr.ɪŋ/}} → {{IPA|[ˈfɪəɹɪŋ]}}). ====Onset==== The following can occur as the [[Syllable onset|onset]]: {| class="wikitable" |- |All single consonant phonemes except {{IPA|/ŋ/}} ||   |- |Stop plus approximant other than {{IPA|/j/}}: {{IPA|/pl/}}, {{IPA|/bl/}}, {{IPA|/kl/}}, {{IPA|/ɡl/}}, {{IPA|/pr/}}, {{IPA|/br/}}, {{IPA|/tr/}},[1] {{IPA|/dr/}},[1] {{IPA|/kr/}}, {{IPA|/ɡr/}}, {{IPA|/tw/}}, {{IPA|/dw/}}, {{IPA|/ɡw/}}, {{IPA|/kw/}}, {{IPA|/pw/}} certain speakers, {{IPA|/tr/}} and {{IPA|/dr/}} tend to affricate, so that ''tree'' resembles "chree", and ''dream'' resembles "jream".{{sfnp|Wells|1990|p=?}}{{sfnp|Read|1986|p=?}}{{citation | contribution=Prescription Jugs | first=Travis | last=Bradley | year=2006 | title=Phonoloblog | url=http://camba.ucsd.edu/phonoloblog/index.php/2006/05/06/prescription-jugs/ | accessdate=2008-06-13 }} This is sometimes transcribed as {{IPA|[tʃr]}} and {{IPA|[dʒr]}} respectively, but the pronunciation varies and may, for example, be closer to {{IPA|[tʂ]}} and {{IPA|[dʐ]}}{{citation | contribution=The jug trade | first=Eric | last=Bakovic | year=2006 | title=Phonoloblog | url=http://camba.ucsd.edu/phonoloblog/index.php/2006/01/31/the-jug-trade/ | accessdate=2008-06-13 }} or with a fricative release similar in quality to the rhotic, i.e. {{IPA|[tɹ̝̊ɹ̥]}}, {{IPA|[dɹ̝ɹ]}}, or {{IPA|[tʂɻ]}}, {{IPA|[dʐɻ]}}. # Some northern and insular Scottish dialects, particularly in the [[Shetlands]], preserve onsets such as {{IPA|/ɡn/}} (as in ''gnaw''), {{IPA|/kn/}} (as in ''knock''), and {{IPA|/wr/}} or {{IPA|/vr/}} (as in ''write'').See Blake et al., ''The Cambridge History of the English Language'', 1992, p.67; R. McColl Millar, ''Northern and Insular Scots'', Edinburgh University Press, 2007, pp.63-64. # Words beginning in unusual consonant clusters that originated in Latinized Greek loanwords tend to drop the first phoneme, as in *{{IPA|/bd/}}, *{{IPA|/fθ/}}, *{{IPA|/ɡn/}}, *{{IPA|/hr/}}, *{{IPA|/kn/}}, *{{IPA|/ks/}}, *{{IPA|/kt/}}, *{{IPA|/kθ/}}, *{{IPA|/mn/}}, *{{IPA|/pn/}}, *{{IPA|/ps/}}, *{{IPA|/pt/}}, *{{IPA|/tm/}}, and *{{IPA|/θm/}}, which have become {{IPA|/d/}} (''bdellium''), {{IPA|/θ/}} (''phthisis''), {{IPA|/n/}} (''gnome''), {{IPA|/r/}} (''rhythm''), {{IPA|/n/}} (''cnidoblast''), {{IPA|/z/}} (''xylophone''), {{IPA|/t/}} (''ctenophore''), {{IPA|/θ/}} (''chthonic''), {{IPA|/n/}} (''mnemonic''), {{IPA|/n/}} (''pneumonia''), {{IPA|/s/}} (''psychology''), {{IPA|/t/}} (''pterodactyl''), {{IPA|/m/}} (''tmesis''), and {{IPA|/m/}} (''asthma''). However, the onsets {{IPA|/sf/}}, {{IPA|/sfr/}}, {{IPA|/skl/}}, {{IPA|/sθ/}}, and {{IPA|/θl/}} have remained intact. # The onset {{IPA|/hw/}} is simplified to {{IPA|/w/}} in the majority of dialects ([[wine–whine merger|''wine''–''whine'' merger]]). # Clusters ending {{IPA|/j/}} typically occur before {{IPA|/uː/}} and before the CURE vowel (General American {{IPA|/ʊr/}}, RP {{IPA|/ʊə/}}); they may also come before the reduced form {{IPA|/ʊ/}} (as in ''ar'''gu'''ment'') or even {{IPA|/ər/}} (in the American pronunciation of ''fi'''gu'''re''). There is an ongoing sound change ([[yod-dropping]]) by which {{IPA|/j/}} as the final consonant in a [[Consonant cluster|cluster]] is being lost. In RP, words with {{IPA|/sj/}} and {{IPA|/lj/}} can usually be pronounced with or without this sound, e.g. {{IPA|[suːt]}} or {{IPA|[sjuːt]}}. For some speakers of English, including some British speakers, the sound change is more advanced and so, for example, General American does not contain the onsets {{IPA|/tj/}}, {{IPA|/dj/}}, {{IPA|/nj/}}, {{IPA|/θj/}}, {{IPA|/sj/}}, {{IPA|/stj/}}, {{IPA|/zj/}}, or {{IPA|/lj/}}. Words that would otherwise begin in these onsets drop the {{IPA|/j/}}: e.g. ''tube'' ({{IPA|/tub/}}), ''during'' ({{IPA|/ˈdʊrɪŋ/}}), ''new'' ({{IPA|/nu/}}), ''Thule'' ({{IPA|/ˈθuli/}}), ''suit'' ({{IPA|/sut/}}), ''student'' ({{IPA|/ˈstudənt/}}), ''Zeus'' ({{IPA|/zus/}}), ''lurid'' ({{IPA|/ˈlʊrɪd/}}). In some dialects, such [[Welsh English]], {{IPA|/j/}} may occur in more combinations; for example in {{IPA|/tʃj/}} (''chew''), {{IPA|/dʒj/}} (''Jew''), {{IPA|/ʃj/}} (''sure''), and {{IPA|/slj/}} (''slew''). # Many clusters beginning with {{IPA|/ʃ/}} and paralleling native clusters beginning with {{IPA|/s/}} are found initially in German and Yiddish loanwords, such as {{IPA|/ʃl/}}, {{IPA|/ʃp/}}, {{IPA|/ʃt/}}, {{IPA|/ʃm/}}, {{IPA|/ʃn/}}, {{IPA|/ʃpr/}}, {{IPA|/ʃtr/}} (in words such as ''[[schlep]], spiel, shtick, schmuck, [[schnapps]], Shprintzen's, strudel''). {{IPA|/ʃw/}} is found initially in the Hebrew loanword [[schwa]]. Before {{IPA|/r/}} however, the native cluster is {{IPA|/ʃr/}}. The opposite cluster {{IPA|/sr/}} is found in loanwords such as ''Sri Lanka'', but this can be nativized by changing it to {{IPA|/ʃr/}}. ;Other onsets Certain English onsets appear only in contractions: e.g. {{IPA|/zbl/}} ('''sblood''), and {{IPA|/zw/}} or {{IPA|/dzw/}} ('''swounds'' or '''dswounds''). Some, such as {{IPA|/pʃ/}} (''pshaw''), {{IPA|/fw/}} (''fwoosh''), or {{IPA|/vr/}} (''vroom''), can occur in [[interjection]]s. An archaic voiceless fricative plus nasal exists, {{IPA|/fn/}} (''fnese''), as does an archaic {{IPA|/snj/}} (''snew''). Several additional onsets occur in [[loan word]]s (with varying degrees of anglicization) such as {{IPA|/bw/}} (''bwana''), {{IPA|/mw/}} (''moiré''), {{IPA|/nw/}} (''noire''), {{IPA|/tsw/}} (''zwitterion''), {{IPA|/zw/}} (''zwieback''), {{IPA|/dv/}} (''Dvorak''), {{IPA|/kv/}} (''kvetch''), {{IPA|/ʃv/}} (''schvartze''), {{IPA|/tv/}} (''Tver''), {{IPA|/tsv/}} (''Zwickau''), {{IPA|/kdʒ/}} (''Kjell''), {{IPA|/kʃ/}} (''Kshatriya''), {{IPA|/tl/}} (''Tlaloc''), {{IPA|/vl/}} (''Vladimir''), {{IPA|/zl/}} (''zloty''), {{IPA|/tsk/}} (''Tskhinvali''), {{IPA|/hm/}} (''Hmong''), and {{IPA|/km/}} (''Khmer''). Some clusters of this type can be converted to regular English phonotactics by simplifying the cluster: e.g. {{IPA|/(d)z/}} (''dziggetai''), {{IPA|/(h)r/}} (''Hrolf''), {{IPA|/kr(w)/}} (''croissant''), {{IPA|/(ŋ)w/}} (''[[Nguyen#Pronunciation|Nguyen]]''), {{IPA|/(p)f/}} (''pfennig''), {{IPA|/(f)θ/}} (''phthalic''), {{IPA|/(t)s/}} (''tsunami''), {{IPA|/(ǃ)k/}} (''!kung''), and {{IPA|/k(ǁ)/}} (''Xhosa''). Others can be replaced by native clusters differing only in [[Voice (phonetics)|voice]]: {{IPA|/zb ~ sp/}} (''sbirro''), and {{IPA|/zɡr ~ skr/}} (''sgraffito''). ====Nucleus==== The following can occur as the [[Syllable nucleus|nucleus]]: *All vowel sounds *{{IPA|/m/}}, {{IPA|/n/}} and {{IPA|/l/}} in certain situations (see below under [[#Word-level patterns|word-level patterns]]) *{{IPA|/r/}} in [[Rhotic and non-rhotic accents|rhotic varieties]] of English (e.g. [[General American]]) in certain situations (see below under [[#Word-level patterns|word-level patterns]]) ====Coda==== Most (in theory, all) of the following except those that end with {{IPA|/s/}}, {{IPA|/z/}}, {{IPA|/ʃ/}}, {{IPA|/ʒ/}}, {{IPA|/tʃ/}} or {{IPA|/dʒ/}} can be extended with {{IPA|/s/}} or {{IPA|/z/}} representing the [[morpheme]] -s/-z. Similarly, most (in theory, all) of the following except those that end with {{IPA|/t/}} or {{IPA|/d/}} can be extended with {{IPA|/t/}} or {{IPA|/d/}} representing the morpheme -t/-d. {{Harvcoltxt|Wells|1990}} argues that a variety of syllable codas are possible in English, even {{IPA|/ntr, ndr/}} in words like ''entry'' {{IPA|/ˈɛntr.ɪ/}} and ''sundry'' {{IPA|/ˈsʌndr.ɪ/}}, with {{IPA|/tr, dr/}} being treated as affricates along the lines of {{IPA|/tʃ, dʒ/}}. He argues that the traditional assumption that pre-vocalic consonants form a syllable with the following vowel is due to the influence of languages like French and Latin, where syllable structure is CVC.CVC regardless of stress placement. Disregarding such contentious cases, which do not occur at the ends of words, the following sequences can occur as the [[Syllable coda|coda]]: {| class="wikitable" |- |The single consonant phonemes except {{IPA|/h/}}, {{IPA|/w/}}, {{IPA|/j/}} and, in [[Rhotic and non-rhotic accents|non-rhotic varieties]], {{IPA|/r/}} ||   |- |Lateral approximant plus stop or affricate: {{IPA|/lp/}}, {{IPA|/lb/}}, {{IPA|/lt/}}, {{IPA|/ld/}}, {{IPA|/ltʃ/}}, {{IPA|/ldʒ/}}, {{IPA|/lk/}} || help, bulb, belt, hold, belch, indulge, milk |- |In rhotic varieties, {{IPA|/r/}} plus stop or affricate: voiceless fricatives: {{IPA|/fθ/}} || fifth |- |Two voiceless stops: {{IPA|/pt/}}, {{IPA|/kt/}} || opt, act |- |Stop plus voiceless fricative: {{IPA|/pθ/}}, {{IPA|/ps/}}, {{IPA|/tθ/}}, {{IPA|/ts/}}, {{IPA|/dθ/}}, {{IPA|/ks/}} || depth, lapse, eighth, klutz, width, box |- |Lateral approximant + two consonants: {{IPA|/lpt/}}, {{IPA|/lps/}}, {{IPA|/lfθ/}}, {{IPA|/lts/}}, {{IPA|/lst/}}, {{IPA|/ŋks/}}, {{IPA|/ŋkθ/}} in some varieties || prompt, glimpse, thousandth, distinct, jinx, length |- |Three obstruents: {{IPA|/ksθ/}}, {{IPA|/kst/}} || sixth, next |} Note: For some speakers, a fricative before {{IPA|/θ/}} is elided so that these never appear phonetically: {{IPA|/fɪfθ/}} becomes {{IPA|[fɪθ]}}, {{IPA|/sɪksθ/}} becomes {{IPA|[sɪkθ]}},{{who|date=January 2015}} {{IPA|/twɛlfθ/}} becomes {{IPA|[twɛlθ]}}. ===Syllable-level patterns=== *Syllables may consist of a single vowel, meaning that onset and coda are not mandatory. *The consonant {{IPA|/ŋ/}} does not occur in syllable-initial position. *The consonant {{IPA|/h/}} does not occur in syllable-final position. *Onset clusters ending in {{IPA|/j/}} are followed by {{IPA|/uː/}} or its variants (see note 5 above). *Long vowels and diphthongs are not found before {{IPA|/ŋ/}}, except for the mimetic words ''boing'' and ''oink'', unassimilated foreign words such as Burmese ''aung'' and proper names such as ''[[Taung]]'', and American-type pronunciations of words like ''strong'' (which have {{IPA|/ɔŋ/}} or {{IPA|/ɑŋ/}}). The short vowels {{IPA|/ɛ, ʊ/}} occur before {{IPA|/ŋ/}} only in assimilated non-native words such as ''[[ginseng]]'' and ''[[Sung Dynasty|Sung]]'' (name of dynasty) or non-finally in some dialects in words like ''strength''. *{{IPA|/ʊ/}} is rare in syllable-initial positionThe OED does not list any native words that begin with {{IPA|/ʊ/}}, apart from mimetic ''oof!, ugh! oops! ook(y)'' (although in the northern half of England, {{IPA|[ʊ]}} is used for {{IPA|/ʌ/}} and is common at the start of syllables). * Stop + {{IPA|/w/}} before {{IPA|/uː, ʊ, ʌ, aʊ/}} (all presently or historically {{IPA|/u(ː)/}}) are excluded.{{sfnp|Clements|Keyser|1983|p=?}} * Sequences of {{IPA|/s/}} + C1 + V̆ + C1, where C1 is a consonant other than {{IPA|/t/}} and V̆ is a short vowel, are virtually nonexistent.{{sfnp|Clements|Keyser|1983|p=?}} ===Word-level patterns=== *{{IPA|/ə/}} does not occur in stressed syllables. *{{IPA|/ʒ/}} does not occur in word-initial position in native English words, although it can occur syllable-initially as in ''luxurious'' {{IPA|/lʌɡˈʒʊəriəs/}}, and at the start of borrowed words such as ''genre''. *{{IPA|/m/}}, {{IPA|/n/}}, {{IPA|/l/}} and, in [[Rhotic and non-rhotic accents|rhotic varieties]], {{IPA|/r/}} can be the syllable nucleus (i.e. a [[syllabic consonant]]) in an unstressed syllable following another consonant, especially {{IPA|/t/}}, {{IPA|/d/}}, {{IPA|/s/}} or {{IPA|/z/}}. Such syllables are often analyzed phonemically as having an underlying {{IPA|/ə/}} as the nucleus. See above under [[#Consonants|Consonants]]. *The short vowels are [[checked and free vowels|checked vowels]], in that they cannot occur without a coda in a word-final stressed syllable. (This does not apply to {{IPA|/ə/}}, which does not occur in stressed syllables at all.) ==Prosody== The [[Prosody (linguistics)|prosodic]] features of English – stress, rhythm, and intonation – can be described as follows. ===Prosodic stress=== '''Prosodic stress''' is extra stress given to words or syllables when they appear in certain positions in an utterance, or when they receive special emphasis. According to Ladefoged's analysis (as referred to under {{slink|Lexical stress}} above), English normally has prosodic stress on the final stressed syllable in an [[intonation unit]]. This is said to be the origin of the distinction traditionally made at the lexical level between primary and secondary stress: when a word like ''admiration'' (traditionally transcribed as something like {{IPA|/ˌædmɪˈreɪʃən/}}) is spoken in isolation, or at the end of a sentence, the syllable ''ra'' (the final stressed syllable) is pronounced with greater force than the syllable ''ad'', although when the word is not pronounced with this final intonation there may be no difference between the levels of stress of these two syllables. Prosodic stress can shift for various [[pragmatics|pragmatic]] functions, such as focus or contrast. For instance, in the dialogue ''Is it brunch tomorrow? No, it's '''dinner''' tomorrow'', the extra stress shifts from the last stressed syllable of the sentence, ''to'''mor'''row'', to the last stressed syllable of the emphasized word, '''''din'''ner.'' Grammatical [[function word]]s are usually prosodically unstressed, although they can acquire stress when emphasized (as in ''Did you find the cat? Well, I found '''a''' cat''). Many English function words have distinct strong and weak pronunciations; for example, the word ''a'' in the last example is pronounced {{IPA|/eɪ/}}, while the more common unstressed ''a'' is pronounced {{IPA|/ə/}}. See [[Weak and strong forms in English]]. ===Rhythm=== English is claimed to be a ''[[Timing (linguistics)|stress-timed]]'' language. That is, stressed syllables tend to appear with a more or less regular rhythm, while non-stressed syllables are shortened to accommodate this. For example, in the sentence ''One make of car is better than another'', the syllables ''one'', ''make'', ''car'', ''bett-'' and ''{{notatypo|-noth-}}'' will be stressed and relatively long, while the other syllables will be considerably shorter. The theory of stress-timing predicts that each of the three unstressed syllables in between ''bett-'' and ''{{notatypo|-noth-}}'' will be shorter than the syllable ''of'' between ''make'' and ''car'', because three syllables must fit into the same amount of time as that available for ''of''. However, it should not be assumed that all varieties of English are stress-timed in this way. The English spoken in the West Indies,{{sfnp|Collins and Mees|2013|p=138}} in Africa{{sfnp|Wells|1982|p=644}} and in India{{sfnp|Wells|1982|pp=630–1}} are probably better characterized as [[Isochrony|syllable-timed]], though the lack of an agreed scientific test for categorizing an accent or language as stress-timed or syllable-timed may lead one to doubt the value of such a characterization.{{sfnp|Roach|1982|pp=73–9}} ===Intonation=== {{hatnote|For more information see {{slink|Intonation (linguistics)|Intonation in English}}}} Phonological contrasts in intonation can be said to be found in three different and independent domains. In the work of Halliday{{sfnp|Halliday|1967|pp=18–24}} the following names are proposed: *''Tonality'' for the distribution of continuous speech into tone groups. *''Tonicity'' for the placing of the principal accent on a particular syllable of a word, making it the ''tonic syllable''. This is the domain also referred to as [[stress (linguistics)#Prosodic stress|prosodic stress]] or [[sentence stress]]. *''Tone'' for the choice of pitch movement on the tonic syllable. (The use of the term ''tone'' in this sense should not be confused with the [[tone (linguistics)|tone]] of tone languages, such as Chinese.) These terms ("the Three Ts") have been used in more recent work,{{sfnp|Tench|1996}}{{sfnp|Wells|2006}} though they have been criticized for being difficult to remember.{{sfnp|Roach|2009|p=144}} American systems such as [[ToBI]] also identify contrasts involving boundaries between intonation phrases (Halliday's ''tonality''), placement of pitch accent (''tonicity''), and choice of tone or tones associated with the pitch accent (''tone''). Example of phonological contrast involving placement of intonation unit boundaries (boundary marked by |): {{ordered list|type=lower-alpha |1=Those who ran quickly {{!}} escaped. (the only people who escaped were those who ran quickly) |2=Those who ran {{!}} quickly escaped. (the people who ran escaped quickly) }} Example of phonological contrast involving placement of tonic syllable (marked by capital letters): {{ordered list|type=lower-alpha |1=I have plans to LEAVE. (= I am planning to leave) |2=I have PLANS to leave. (= I have some drawings to leave) }} Example of phonological contrast (British English) involving choice of tone (\ = falling tone, \/ = fall-rise tone) {{ordered list|type=lower-alpha |1=She didn't break the record because of the \ WIND. (= she did not break the record, because the wind held her up) |2=She didn't break the record because of the \/ WIND. (= she did break the record, but not because of the wind) }} There is typically a contrast involving tone between [[wh-question]]s and [[yes/no question]]s, the former having a falling tone (e.g. "Where did you \PUT it?") and the latter a rising tone (e.g. "Are you going /OUT?"), though studies of spontaneous speech have shown frequent exceptions to this rule.{{sfnp|Brown|1990|pp=122–3}} [[Tag questions]] asking for information are said to carry rising tones (e.g. "They are coming on Tuesday, /AREN'T they?") while those asking for confirmation have falling tone (e.g. "Your name's John, \ISN'T it."). ==History of English pronunciation== {{Main|Phonological history of English}} The pronunciation system of English has undergone many changes throughout the history of the language, from the [[Old English phonology|phonological system of Old English]], to [[Middle English phonology|that of Middle English]], through to that of the present day. Variation between [[English dialects|dialects]] has always been significant. Former pronunciations of many words are reflected in their spellings, as [[English orthography]] has generally not kept pace with phonological changes since the Middle English period. The English consonant system has been relatively stable over time, although [[Phonological history of English consonants|a number of significant changes]] have occurred. Examples include the loss (in most dialects) of the {{IPA|[ç]}} and {{IPA|[x]}} sounds still reflected by the {{angbr|gh}} in words like ''night'' and ''taught'', and the splitting of voiced and voiceless allophones of fricatives into separate phonemes (such as the two different [[Pronunciation of English ⟨th⟩|phonemes represented by {{angbr|th}}]]). There have also been many [[Phonological history of English consonant clusters|changes in consonant clusters]], mostly reductions, for instance those that produced the usual modern pronunciations of such letter combinations as {{angbr|wr-}}, {{angbr|kn-}} and [[English wh|{{angbr|wh-}}]]. The [[Phonological history of English vowels|development of vowels]] has been much more complex. One of the most notable series of changes is that known as the [[Great Vowel Shift]], which began around the late 14th century. Here the {{IPA|[iː]}} and {{IPA|[uː]}} in words like ''price'' and ''mouth'' became diphthongized, and other long vowels became higher: {{IPA|[eː]}} became {{IPA|[iː]}} (as in ''meet''), {{IPA|[aː]}} became {{IPA|[eː]}} and later {{IPA|[eɪ]}} (as in ''name''), {{IPA|[oː]}} became {{IPA|[uː]}} (as in ''goose''), and {{IPA|[ɔː]}} became {{IPA|[oː]}} and later {{IPA|[oʊ]}} (in RP now {{IPA|[əʊ]}}; as in ''bone''). These shifts are responsible for the modern pronunciations of many written vowel combinations, including those involving a [[silent e|silent final {{angbr|e}}]]. Many other changes in vowels have taken place over the centuries (see the separate articles on the [[Phonological history of English low back vowels|low back]], [[Phonological history of English high back vowels|high back]] and [[Phonological history of English high front vowels|high front]] vowels, [[Phonological history of English short A|short A]], and [[Phonological history of English diphthongs|diphthongs]]). These various changes mean that many words that formerly rhymed (and may be expected to rhyme based on their spelling) no longer do.{{sfnp|Cercignani|1975|pp=513–8}} For example, in [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]]'s time, following the Great Vowel Shift, ''food'', ''good'' and ''blood'' all had the vowel {{IPA|[uː]}}, but in modern pronunciation ''good'' has been shortened to {{IPA|[ʊ]}}, while ''blood'' has been shortened and lowered to {{IPA|[ʌ]}} in most accents. In other cases, words that were formerly distinct have come to be pronounced the same – examples of such mergers include [[Meet–meat merger|''meet–meat'']], [[Pane–pain merger|''pane–pain'']] and [[Toe–tow merger|''toe–tow'']]. ==See also== {{colbegin|colwidth=25em}} * [[Australian English phonology]] * [[English orthography]] * [[English pronunciation of Greek letters]] * [[General American]] * [[Non-native pronunciations of English]] * [[Old English phonology]] * [[Perception of English /r/ and /l/ by Japanese speakers]] * [[Phonological development]] * [[Phonological history of English vowels]] * [[Phonological history of English consonants]] * [[Pronunciation of English ⟨th⟩]] * [[Received Pronunciation]] * [[Regional accents of English]] * [[Rhoticity in English]] *
